awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Smart prismatic-louver technology for enhanced daylighting and management of thermal loads in green buildings
awd_abstract_narration:
The project will develop nanofluid-filled louvers that can be used as light blocking devices, as well as visible light redirectors and solar infrared energy absorbers and manipulators. The louvers through their optical transparency to visible light and optical properties redirect the incoming collimated sunlight so that natural lighting improvement and management for deeper daylight penetration are achieved, reducing lighting electrical power cost. In addition, reduced glare and offsetting of artificial lighting needs can be accomplished, increasing occupants' comfort. The faculty and students involved in the project will organize lectures and workshops to share their results to the local community to inform of the possible benefits of the research. The integrated education and research program will enhance recruitment and outreach to various underrepresented communities at the two public universities that serve a large population of underrepresented students in STEM. Daylight is an important aspect of everyday life inside buildings, as it enhances individual productivity, increases student performance and well-being. The project has the potential to have an impact in the perception of and adaptation of older buildings to contemporary uses by virtue of sustainable energy technology. The project results offer a better working environment, reducing the energy requirements and the carbon footprint of buildings.


The major objective of this project is to study the fundamental optics and thermal-fluid mechanisms for enhanced daylighting, enhanced solar infrared (IR) energy harvesting, and enhanced energy transport, via use of proposed nanofluid-filled prismatic louvers. In particular, the project will study the effects of the prismatic louver geometry, orientation and control in glazings, and the photothermal physics of nanofluids for achieving: (a) Visible light redirection and diffusion and smart control for better natural light penetration in the indoors, and (b) Selective radiation absorption through IR absorption-enhanced nanofluid for heat gain manipulation of the incoming solar radiation. The specific aims of the project include: (i) Optical analysis and experimental verification of enhanced daylighting; (ii) Spectral analysis of selected nanofluids for enhanced solar IR radiation harvesting; (iii) Thermal analysis and measurements for enhanced heat transfer and energy storage; and (iv) Daylighting and thermal management control for realizing a smart louver system. The project will develop prismatic louver geometries and orientations for optimum daylighting condition for a variety of climatic zones. At the same time, nanofluids (e.g., low-volume TiO2 nanoparticles in water) tailored for selectively increasing solar IR absorption/harvesting but not affecting visible light penetration will be developed and studied. An important objective of this project is to study the interplay between increased daylight penetration and the effects on reducing heating/cooling needs. This is required to effectively manage both the incoming light and solar radiation, by proper control of light redirection and heat transfer to either the surrounding environment, or to secondary heat exchanging and/or thermal storage tank, or to thermoelectricity generators. Theoretical and experimental work in both optics and heat transfer issues are addressed. For the first time to the project team's knowledge, the project addresses solar IR energy harvesting, regulation and management in a way that makes optimal use of their impact through an integrated and adaptable design that can address different climatic, and seasonal needs. The project through its hybrid methods and results, e.g., lighting and sun-shading, energy savings, thermal load reduction and nanofluid-based heat storage/transfer allows for the conversion of natural resources, achieving green energy and sustainability.

por.por_cntn:
This collaborative project is aimed to study the fundamental optics and thermal-fluid mechanisms in the proposed nanofluid-filled prismatic louver device for improved daylighting and enhanced solar energy harvesting. Focus is on the effects of the prismatic louver geometry, orientation and control in glazing, and the photothermal physics of nanofluids for achieving dual-purpose: improving natural illumination in the indoors and harvesting solar thermal energy from the windows. It is targeted at reducing the energy consumption and cutting the electrical bills for the buildings, in which about 58% of the consumed energy is used for lighting and space heating. The building sector is the largest energy consumer in the USA, consuming approximately 74% of the nation?s total electricity and accounting for nearly 40% of the nation's man-made carbon dioxide emission. 

 

The proposed glass prismatic louver can transmit visible (VIS) light and redirect the direct irradiation to ceiling to eliminate the ?glare effect?, improving daylighting quality and occupants? comfortableness. Water-based nanofluid flows through the hollow louver and tune the solar spectrum such that VIS passes through for daylighting but infrared (IR) and ultraviolet (UV) light are absorbed and converted into thermal energy for heating purpose.  In this way, we provide a third technology for utilizing the green and renewable solar energy in addition to the solar cells and concentrated solar power. We do not utilize solar power in a specific band but look at how the full solar spectrum is explored.

 

We investigated the louver filled with water. A 7-band spectral model for spectral investigation of solar irradiation was proposed. The influence of solar air mass on the absorption efficiency and VIS transmittance was found to be small. Thus, the device would work worldwide. Both the glass and water absorb IR radiation strongly. The glass absorbs the UV strongly. The water absorbs little UV and VIS. VIS transmittance is very high and the majority UV light can be blocked, reducing UV overexposure of occupants. Most of the absorbed solar energy by the glass can be converted into thermal energy in the water through heat convection.  The pumping power consumed is negligible in comparison with the solar energy harvested. Results show that the louver device facing normally to direct sunlight can harvest 51?54% of the total solar energy and transmit 74?76% VIS. Under general US solar condition, VIS transmittance reaches 76%; the absorption of UV and IR reaches 80-85% and 64-82%, respectively. In three places tested, the device absorbs about 81-82% IR and 87-88% UV, and transmits about 76% VIS. The total solar energy absorption efficiency reaches 53?56%. A single louver could harvest about 25-35 W thermal energy, whereas a typical window of 3? by 6? could have 20 louvers installed. An overall utilization efficiency is the sum of the illumination efficiency and the solar-thermal efficiency. The dual usage of the proposed louver makes its overall utilization efficiency as high as 87-90%. 

 

Various nanofluids were compared concerning nanoparticle (NP) type, size, and concentration. We found that 0.00004 vol.% Ni NPs of 80 nm in size could be added into water to optimize the enhancement of solar energy harvest while provide required daylighting. Under typical US solar condition, a louver filled with such Ni-water nanofluid can transmit 46.5% VIS for daylighting and harvests 65.7% of the total solar energy. The harvested thermal energy is increased by 25.9% compared to the water case. Although the VIS amount for daylighting is reduced with use of nanofluid, it is still sufficient. We introduced a criterion to ensure at least 45% VIS for daylighting at cloudy days. At such a dilute concentration, most of the thermal-fluid properties of the nanofluid except for its optical properties are not much affected by the variations of nanofluid models. Neither aggregation of NPs is a concern.

 

This is a collaborative project between CCNY and Rutgers. The CCNY team has fabricated the louvers and developed an experimental setup with an automated motion control system. Both investigators at CCNY and Rutgers met frequently and worked closely. The research at Rutgers has resulted in the publication of nine journal papers, six conference papers, one PhD dissertation, two MS theses. It has been disseminated in three plenary and three keynote talks in international conferences. It has trained two PhD students, two Master of Science and three Master of Engineering students, and 51 undergraduate students.
